flow.descriptionCdata:
1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.0ff8fdb4-539f-4459-aebb-31ffe56c824b.description=
Runs a command, allowing you to specify whether it runs locally (no port to be specified), via SSH, Global Shell, ROSH, Telnet, or RSH.

Inputs\:
    host - The host name or IP address.
    port - The port number used to connect to the host.
    username - The user name used to connect.
    password - The password associated with the  input. If using a private key file, this is the passphrase for the file.
    protocol - The protocol used to run the command. 
Examples\: SSH, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, REXEC, local, WMI, NASConnectTelnet, HPOM
    timeout - The time to wait for the command to complete (in milliseconds). Increase this value if you are getting incomplete output results or a timeout.
Default value\: 90000
    command - The command to run.
    arguments - The arguments to pass to the command.
    environment - Specifies the environment variables and values that need to be defined when running the command.
    startDir - The path to the starting directory.
    pty - Specifies whether to use pty (used by SSH, GlobalShell)
Valid values\: true, false
    privateKeyFile - The path to the private key file, relative to ICONCLUDE_HOME on the RAS host (used by SSH, GlobalShell).
    sasHost - The host on which to run the ROSH command.
    sasHostUsername - The user name used to run the ROSH command on .
    usernamePrompt - The prompt message for the user name. Used by the Telnet protocol. When used by the NASConnectTelnet protocol, the default value is 'NAS Login\:'.
    passwordPrompt - The prompt message for the password associated with the < usernamePrompt > input. Used by the Telnet protocol.  When used by the 'NASConnectTelnet' protocol, the default value is 'Password\:'
    outputPath - The network accessible path where to store the temporary files. If you do not specify this input, it points to '\\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible, change it to use another share to which the host local system account has write access. By default, the path needs to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    nasDevice - The NAS device on which to run the command when using the 'NASConnect' protocol.
    nasDeviceConsoleMode - The NAS device console mode used to run the command scripts running the command on the specified NAS device. If you leave this input empty, command scripts are not used, and the connections to the NAS device and the command are issued directly in the console. This is not recommended. Due to error handling capabilities limitation, the result might be a success even if the command failed to run. You can find the values for this input in the NAS web interface, as a drop-down list when creating a new command script (for example, Cisco IOS enable).
    hpomNode - The node on which to run the command.
    hpomProtocol - The protocol used to communicate with HPOM (HTTP or HTTPS).
    characterSet - The name of the character set used for stream encoding and decoding between the RAS and target machine.
Default value\: UTF-8 (used by SSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, REXEC)
Examples\: SJIS,EUC-JP, UTF-8

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. Used to determine the operation response, specifying whether the operation is successful or not.
    stdOut - The standard output (STDOUT) of the command.
    stdErr - The standard error (STDERR) of the command.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Notes\:
Telnet protocol - Since telnet is shell protocol, not a remote execution protocol, the response is always  successful if the command is ran in the remote shell.  The return code of the specified command cannot be determined in this protocol.  If you must use the telnet protocol with this operation, make sure to check the command results. Consider using the SSH or REXEC protocol instead.
1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.1f7b4702-8678-42c1-836a-67794bd7db98.description=
 Detects the operating system that is running on the specified host.

Inputs\:
    host - The host to connect to.
    username - The username to use when connecting.
    password - The password to use when connecting.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. The name and the version of the operating system.
    osName - The completely returned string of the OS name.
    version - The operating systems version.
    hostName - The host name the remote computer reports for itself.
    enterprise - 'true' if the operating system is an enterprise edition
    server - 'true' if the operating system is a server edition
    professional - 'true' if the operating system is a professional edition.
    standard - 'true' if the operating system is a standard edition.

Responses\:
    windows - Remote host is running a version of windows.
    linux - Remote host is running linux.
    solaris - Remote host is running solaris.
    other unix - Remote host appears to be unix based, but is an unknown variant.
    failure - System could not determine remote hosts operating system.

Notes\:
1. The enterprise, server, professional and standard results give more details about what version of windows is detected and are always set to 'false' if a unix system is being run.
2. The operation returns the output of a uname -a for unix based hosts, and the results of osName and version WMI queries for a windows host.
1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.4379767f-7265-4dc4-b73b-b48046d72389.callout=Sets the variable ${remoteOS} to WINDOWS. The variable will be used by the ping step. 1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.629eda65-8204-4505-8cd1-bde8ef51d880.callout=This flow restarts the host and then pings it to make sure it is available. The first step detects the operating system, and if this step is successful the actual restart is performed. After the restart, the flow sleeps for a specified number of seconds. Finally, it pings the host to make sure that after the restart the system is responsive again. 1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.7f3ef064-51f7-411c-856d-8a225a18e4e4.callout=Detects the operating system. The host input is required. 1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.87a7661c-5724-4d3f-9752-1de71bd0d232.description=Counts from one number to another number. 
Inputs\:
from - The number to start counting at.
to - The number to count to.
incrementBy - The number to increment by while counting. If unspecified this is 1. If you wanted to count 2,4,6,8 this would be 2.
reset - If true, then the counter will restart counting from the beginning.

NOTE\: These values must be between -9223372036854775808 and 9223372036854775807

Returns\:
The number that was just counted.

Note\: the primary result is resultString, Result can also be used. result (All lower case) should not be used as it is the response code.

Responses\:
has more - Not yet done counting.
no more - Done counting. This will only be returned once, then counting restarts.
failure - Something went wrong.
1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.8fc2f5cf-13c9-4022-9e44-8d750c2947e3.callout=Sets the variable ${remoteOS} to LINUX. The variable will be used by the ping step. 1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.9abf37d9-8d42-4fed-9872-e7dc7c50cb7d.callout=Restarts the Windows server 1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.9bdae85b-f753-4af0-a064-413f311637c2.description=
Sleeps for the number of seconds specified in the input.

Inputs\:
seconds - The number of seconds to sleep.

Responses\:
success - Slept for the number of seconds given as input.
failure - Was unable to sleep for some reason.
1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.9f24e1da-7a93-47be-9b3f-cf1f07d67eb1.callout=Loop for ${nbTries} times ( default is 5 ) to sleep and then ping the server. 1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.b906d3ea-d1d5-4b76-91ae-99b4b8dfaf01.callout=Restarts the Linux server. 1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.bcb40af4-4554-4017-94c7-3bc4935adb7b.description=
Uses WMI to attempt to create a remote process on a machine.  The command passed should be formatted as though it was run on the command line.

CAUTION\: internally 'cmd /c' gets prepended to the command passed.  Also '2>tempfile 1>tempfile' get appended to the command so that we can attempt to capture stdout and stderr.
So your command will look like this when executed\:
	'cmd /c [yourcommand] 2>temperr 1>tempout'

Inputs\:
    host - Hostname or ip address of the target machine.
    command - The command you want executed. Special characters\: <, >, (, ), & need to be escaped using the caret (^) character.  The only exception to this rule is when the > character is used to redirect output.
    user - Username to use for remote WMI impersonation and thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation (can be left blank).
    password - Password of the user.
    outputPath - Network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified it points to \\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default the path will have to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    currentDirectory - Current directory.
    characterSet - The character encoding used to write the batch file that will be remotely executed by the operation. Unicode character encodings may not supported for this input (utf-8, utf-16, etc.).  Support for unicode encodings depends on target system capabilities.  By default this encoding will also be used to read the command output that is redirected to temporary files.  If the command output is expected to be of different encoding, specify the different encoding in the outputCharacterSet input.  Default value\: The encoding of the operating system where is RAS installed.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis
    outputCharacterSet - The character encoding used to read the command output that was redirected to temporary files.  Only need to specify this input if the output of the command is known to output a different character encoding.  As an example\: the 'wmic' command returns utf-16 encoded output.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis, utf-8, utf-16
    timeout - The number of seconds before assuming the remote process is no longer functional. After the timeout has expired the remote process and all child processes will be terminated.
Default value\: 90

Responses\:
    success - Remote process successfully launched and has completed executing.
    failure - Unable to start remote process.

Results\:
    returnResult - Return value from WMI for starting the process (not the exit value of the process).
    processID - The process id of the remote process.
    processReturnCode - The return code of the remote process.
    stdOut - Standard output from the remote process.
    stdErr - Standard error from the remote process.

Notes\: 
List of possible encoding names (Support for the encoding may depend on the version or language of the RAS OS)\:

Encoding Name\:	Description\:
IBM437		OEM United States
DOS-720		Arabic (DOS)
ibm737		Greek (DOS)
ibm775		Baltic (DOS)
ibm850		Western European (DOS)
ibm852		Central European (DOS)
IBM855		OEM Cyrillic
ibm857		Turkish (DOS)
IBM00858		OEM Multilingual Latin I
IBM860		Portuguese (DOS)
ibm861		Icelandic (DOS)
DOS-862		Hebrew (DOS)
IBM863		French Canadian (DOS)
IBM864		Arabic (864)
IBM865		Nordic (DOS)
cp866		Cyrillic (DOS)
ibm869		Greek, Modern (DOS)
shift_jis		Japanese (Shift-JIS)
gb2312		Chinese Simplified (GB2312)
ks_c_5601-1987	Korean
big5		Chinese Traditional (Big5)
utf-16		Unicode
unicodeFFFE		Unicode (Big-Endian)
utf-7		Unicode (UTF-7)
utf-8		Unicode (UTF-8)
utf-32		Unicode (UTF-32)
utf-32BE		Unicode (UTF-32 Big-Endian)
Johab		Korean (Johab)
us-ascii		US-ASCII
koi8-r		Cyrillic (KOI8-R)
euc-jp		Japanese (EUC)
EUC-CN		Chinese Simplified (EUC)
euc-kr		Korean (EUC)
hz-gb-2312		Chinese Simplified (HZ)
GB18030		Chinese Simplified (GB18030)
1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.c13e70df-8bcf-49f7-a0bc-3b7082a4fc26.callout=Pings the server to check if it is responding after the restart. 1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.c3058414-03ba-43f3-b68d-dd9c84b9e44e.description=
Adds a flow variable into the local context (available to itself and child flows only)

Input Parameters\:
keyName - the name of the flow variable to use
myValue - the value to assign the flow variable

Responses\:
success - assigned the flow variable

Scriptlet Example\:
[$scriptletContext putGlobal\: $keyName, $myValue];
1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.description=
This flow detects the operating system of a given host, initiates a restart for the host, sleeps for a specified number of seconds and then pings the host to make sure it is reachable again.

Inputs\:
    host - The hostname or IP address of the system to shutdown/restart.
    username - The user to connect to the host.
    password - The password to connect to the host.

Responses\:
    success - Server restart completed successfully.
    failure - An error occurred during the detection of the operating system of the server, during the actual restart process or during the pinging of the server after the restart completed.

Results\:
   returnResult - This is the primary output. When the execution is successful, this will contain information retrieved by the ping step. In the event of a failure, it will contain details about the error.
   osName - This result contains the result of the detection of the operating system for the specified host.
   exception - This result contains information about the cause of the failure.

Note\: 

The are two hidden inputs that allow to specify the number of attempts to ping and the number of seconds that the flow sleeps before each ping.

    nbTries - The number of attempts of pinging the server to make sure it is reachable again.
Default value\: 5
    sleepInterval - The number of seconds the flow sleeps before pinging.
Default value\: 20

In order to use this functionality, the inputs must be added for every step of 'Restart Server'.

If none of the ping attempts suceed, the execution will end with a warning.
1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.ed4309fa-1321-431f-8d1c-edfb8e325592.callout=Sleeps for ${sleepInterval} seconds. Default is 20 seconds. 1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.ef5a2d17-8663-4c54-aa0b-d0a4c09ae446.description=
Runs a Ping command either locally or remotely depending on the specified protocol. Credentials and other inputs (remoteOS, hostname, username, password, keyFile etc) are required if the command must be run from a remote host. The Telnet protocol also requires inputs for usernamePrompt and passwordPrompt. 

Inputs\:
    hostname - Hostname or IP address of the host computer where the Ping command will be executed.
    username - A username to authenticate to the host computer. 
    password - The password for the user account.
    targetHost - Hostname or IP address of the target host computer.
    protocol  - The protocol used to run the command.
Valid values\: local, ssh, Telnet
    packetSize - The size of the ping packet.
    packetCount - The number of ping packets to send.
    remoteOS - The operating system of the host computer (WINDOWS, LINUX, SOLARIS only are supported), if Ping is running on a remote host.
    usernamePrompt - The username prompt seen while using Telnet protocol. This input is required when Telnet protocol is used. For example, login\:.
    passwordPrompt - The password prompt seen while using Telnet protocol. This input is required when Telnet protocol is used. For example, password\:.
    keyFile - The path to the private key file for remote host. The path should be absolute.
    timeout - The timeout in miliseconds for the Ping operation. Default is 90000.

Responses\:
    success - The command executed successfully.
    failure - The command could not be executed or had a problem during execution.

Returns\:
    packetsSent - The number of packets sent.
    packetsReceived - The number of packets received.
    percentagePacketsLost - The percentage of packets lost.
    transmissionTimeMin - Minimum time taken for transmitting the packet.
    transmissionTimeMax - Maximum time taken for transmitting the packet.
    transmissionTimeAvg - Average time taken for transmitting the packet.
    returnResult - Raw output of the command.
    returnCode - Return code of the executed command.
    error - The STDERR of the command.
1d845c9e-b8e1-49c9-9689-731c218cd082.f7f074dc-5926-4c1b-bd46-a168af9bea52.description=
Adds a flow variable into the local context (available to itself and child flows only)

Input Parameters\:
keyName - the name of the flow variable to use
myValue - the value to assign the flow variable

Responses\:
success - assigned the flow variable

Scriptlet Example\:
[$scriptletContext putGlobal\: $keyName, $myValue];
flow.name: Restart Server
